message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab findings suggest that the patient has glomerulonephritis, which commonly occurs as a result of a streptococcal infection. Therefore, a positive streptozyme test is a likely laboratory finding. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate may be elevated due to inflammation, and the C3 level may be decreased due to consumption. The ASO titer may or may not be elevated, as it is not always a reliable indicator of a recent streptococcal infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the history of sore throat suggest post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. The presence of RBC and granular casts in the urine, as well as the smoky appearance of the urine, indicate glomerular injury. One of the diagnostic tests for post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a positive streptozyme test. Therefore, option B is the correct answer. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate may or may not be elevated in this condition, so option A is incorrect. Increased C3 level and negative ASO titer are not typical findings in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, so options C and D are also incorrect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and lab results suggest acute glomerulonephritis, which can be caused by a streptococcal infection. Streptozyme test detects antibodies against streptococcal antigens and is positive in such cases. ASO titer and C3 level may also be increased, but the streptozyme test is the most specific. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is usually increased in acute inflammation, so option (A) is incorrect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including facial puffiness and smoky urine, suggest glomerulonephritis, which can be caused by a streptococcal infection. The positive streptozyme test reflects the presence of antibodies against streptococcal antigens, indicating a recent streptococcal infection. The ASO titer may also be elevated in streptococcal infections, but it is not as specific as the streptozyme test. The C3 level may be decreased in glomerulonephritis, but it is not a consistent finding. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate is not specific to any diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest nephritis, which is commonly associated with post-streptococcal infection. The streptozyme test is used to diagnose a recent streptococcal infection. Therefore, a positive streptozyme test can be expected in this patient. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is typically elevated in nephritis, so option (A) is incorrect. Increased C3 level and negative ASO titer are also associated with post-streptococcal infection, but they are not as specific to nephritis as the streptozyme test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of glomerulonephritis, which is a common complication of a streptococcal infection such as strep throat. The positive streptozyme test indicates a recent streptococcal infection, which is the likely cause of the glomerulonephritis. The ASO titer may also be elevated in this situation, but it is not as specific as the streptozyme test. The C3 level may be decreased in glomerulonephritis, but it is not as specific as the streptozyme test. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate may be elevated in inflammation, but it is not specific to this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest glomerulonephritis, which can be caused by streptococcal infection. The streptozyme test is used to diagnose a recent streptococcal infection, while ASO titer is used to diagnose a past streptococcal infection. C3 level may be decreased in glomerulonephritis, but not necessarily increased. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate may be elevated but not necessarily normal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient likely has post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) due to a recent streptococcal infection. The most likely laboratory finding would be a positive streptozyme test, which detects antibodies to several streptococcal antigens. The ASO titer may be negative. The C3 level may be decreased, but not increased. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate may be elevated, as shown in the patient's report.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination findings, and laboratory results suggest glomerulonephritis, which can be caused by a post-streptococcal infection. The positive streptozyme test indicates a recent streptococcal infection, while a negative ASO titer would suggest an absence of a recent streptococcal infection. Increased C3 level may also be seen in glomerulonephritis, but it is not specific. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate can also be elevated in glomerulonephritis, but it is not necessarily a laboratory finding that can be expected in all patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest glomerulonephritis, and the laboratory findings indicate hematuria and proteinuria, which support this diagnosis. Positive streptozyme test indicates a recent streptococcal infection, which is commonly associated with post-infectious glomerulonephritis. The other options are not specifically related to glomerulonephritis.
